title: Adding new file_mounts cannot be done without setup again
body: When the user adds a new file_mounts, they may only want to upload a new file to the cluster, but they have to run the setup again with `sky launch`. Not sure if we can figure out a way to get rid of this, otherwise we can tell them to just use `rsync`.

title: Alias python to python3
body: AWS AMI's python is a link to python2. We may consider alias python to python3.

title: [Logging] Add hints when yaml.safe_load fails
body:
We may need add the following hints to the logging, when we found yaml.safe_load fail.
1. Check the existence of the yaml file
2. Check the syntax of the yaml file (tab / space)

title: [Logging] Large file_mounts / workdir logging improvement
body:
1. Hint the user to use `.gitignore` when warning about large files
2. The warning does not consider `.gitignore`, even the actual uploading size is small. This is a bit confusing to the user.
3. Add `tail -f ./log_path/sync_workdir.log` and `tail -f ./log_path/file_mounts.log` hints to the logging, for the user to see the progress.

title: [Docs] Clarify the setup / run section is executed under `~/sky_workdir`
Docs: significantly de-ink quickstart
body:
Changes to quickstart
- Changed the two disconnected examples by only keeping hello_sky
  - Rationale - after Daniel we decided to add the first, easy "mygpu" section because he directly modified "hello_sky" and encountered friction.  But that created a lot of friction and waiting time for Kevin.  Upon reviewing Daniel's video, I saw that his friction could've been avoided if he copy-pasted hello_sky.  Added a lot of directional words this time.
- De-ink (shorten) a lot of text, make it much more skimmable / copy-pastable

A few polishing changes to other pages (e.g., moved some content out of quickstart).

Tested
- rendered locally

title: Copy local user .gitconfig to remote VM
body:
This is useful in the event that I push from the VM and would save me a couple minutes of time each time I spin up a VM and accidentally make a commit with name "Ubuntu" and email "ubuntu@....".

I believe Daniel also asked about the possibility of copying up `.vimrc` but not sure how best to support this configuration pattern for lots of different dotfiles.

title: ray does not support Mac OS X 10.x
body: We can only install `ray==1.5` on Mac OS X 10.x, which is OS version of Kevin's laptop.

title: Add price and resource details to `sky status`
body:
Inspired by AI2's beaker tool, it would be nice to make `sky status` more informative.
![Screen Shot 2022-03-10 at 2 34 28 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2015126/157766446-54a4372e-89a9-470b-97c3-0d698e9479d3.png)

Cluster price in the status table seems like an easy one to show right now, along with potentially other finer-grained attributes like RAM/other stuff we already have in the catalog (definitely more informative than just `AWS(m4.2xlarge)`).

title: Non-interactive SSH forwarding in task run script
body:
#533 handles running SSH connections with agent forwarding (such as cloning a git repo). This is possible because we can use the `ForwardAgent yes` flag when making the SSH connection, but since we submit run scripts with Ray and do not use SSH this is not currently possible. 

This means users can't make SSH connections that rely on their local SSH agent e.g. clone a private git repo from `run: ` section.

title: Add copy button to code blocks in documentation
body:
Makes life a bit easier to copy from our documentation. See: https://sphinx-copybutton.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html for more info

### Tests
- [x] Rendered docs locally with correct copy behavior
- [x] Build on RTD with private branch to test functionality

title: Fix non-interactive SSH commands in task setup
body:
This PR fixes a bug found by @concretevitamin. It adds SSH agent forwarding back to the SSH options list and skips the yes/no check required by GitHub/other hosts the first time a user makes an SSH connection with a host (this can be a problem when a user non-interactively performs an SSH connection, such as through git cloning in run/setup).


### Tested
```
# above.yaml
setup:
  git clone git@github.com:sky-proj/sky.git
```
```
sky launch above.yaml
```
Verified sky exist on machine.

### TODO (not for this PR)
Get SSH forwarding to work for `run:`. This is more difficult due to the fact that we submit jobs with Ray and not via direct SSH where we can control these parameters. Filed in #535

title: Fix help str for aws/azure credential check
body: As title.

title: Extend sky show-gpus to show all machine types
body: I wanted a specific CPU machine (e.g. Standard_E8as_v4 on Azure) but couldn't find any details about it in `sky show-gpus` since it isn't a GPU-backed instance. It would be nice to make `sky show-gpus` a general catalog with all possible hardware types sky can offer.

title: Optimize the `ray up` for the second `sky launch`

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body: The second `sky launch` still takes about 30 seconds to run `ray up`, even the cluster is already correctly launched. We may need to optimize that. Probably related to `pip3 install ray` again or `pip3 uninstall -y sky; pip3 install sky_whl`.

title: Fix aws apt install

**Before:**
1. `ray up` takes 184.23 seconds, 
2. `ray up` again (by `sky launch -c`) takes 27.53 seconds. (This should be optimized later as well -- filed an issue #530)

2. `ray up` again (by `sky launch -c`) takes 26.65 seconds.

```yaml
resources:

setup: |

run: |
```

title: [RFC] Sky Storage Mounting Proposal
body:
[This has been discussed on slack and elsewhere, but posting here for posterity]

We are planning to implement read-write mounting for sky.Storage objects. This would greatly simplify data egress once tasks are complete and also enable new use-cases e.g. using spot instances for training.

More details are in the [proposal](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uVNTWk44lvzPFTr9flfPZrs-sT6fiKlqnAPROprwEmU/edit?usp=sharing). Comments are welcome!

title: [Demo][WIP] Storage mounting
body:
This PR serves as a functioning demo for the upcoming storage mounting feature. This MVP has been implemented on AWS/S3 using [goofys](https://github.com/kahing/goofys). 

To try it out:
1. Checkout `storagemounting` branch
2. Edit [examples/storage_mount_demo.yaml](https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/compare/storagemounting?expand=1#diff-66dc0deb8c3775e2779da6f5ccf762ccc25a474921c84f7f351a9d888d028401) and specify a custom bucket name (instead of `romil-fs`)
3. Do whatever you'd like in `setup` and `run`.
4. `sky launch storage_mount_demo.yaml`
5. Install goofys on your laptop and view the results locally with `goofys <bucket> <mntpath>`

Also tested working for multinode mounting (`num_nodes: 2`).

Ignore the code quality, ignore the failing tests - this is intended to be a demo PR and will not be merged.

Commands for reproducing the bug:

```bash
sky launch examples/minimal.yaml --docker -c aa -y

sky exec bb -- pwd
```

title: Docs: Add instructions for quota requests on all clouds
body: By default, accounts on all three clouds are not granted quotas for high end GPU instances such as V100. Let's write a clean guideline for users on how to submit quota requests.

- Revamped "Syncing Code and Artifacts" quite a lot

Tested:

body: We have many examples in the `examples/` folder, and the new user can find it quite confusing about which one to follow. We may need to create subfolders to categorize those examples.

Also

Closes #520.

He was confused by README because there's a YAML example that is placed before the Installation section. We should remove this and try to keep the README short/defer to the official docs.

Also we should remove `pip install azure-cli==2.30.0` from the README/docs since it is already in setup.py.

title: Investigate botocore.exception.ClientError: an error occurred (PendingVerification) error when requesting 4xV100
body: This error came up for the first time during Kevin's onboarding and we should investigate to see what the source of this is.

title: Surface error messages or crash faster during setup
body:
From Kevin's onboarding: When git clone failed - “I wasn’t sure where the error happened”. 

Can we RED all stdout/stderr when something is wrong? We can also try crashing faster by setting -e for the setup and run scripts (note: this will require modifying some of our own examples which use `conda activate xyz` failures to determine whether to create a new environment).

title: Docs: Add "Running your project on Sky" section
body:
Kevin was not clear on how to start porting his project over to sky or the correct workflow to follow. We should make this more clear with a page dedicated to this in the docs.

Context:
He’s not clear when to start porting his project; we manually reminded him that not all tutorial pages need to be followed.  
- Action - We should add more directions / add a page like “Running your project on Sky”.
- He used the Tutorial: DNN Training page as the starting point - really good.
- Consider adding “workdir”.  Although, the current  YAML fits Kevin’s workflow very well.

title: Docs: Shorten quickstart
body:
During our session with Kevin we noticed several issues with the quickstart docs:
- We should make it clear that `sky status` needs to be run locally and not on the provisioned cluster
- Not good to have 2 sections disconected, the second "Hello, Sky" section should reuse mygpu provisioned earlier in the setup.
- Text is too long for https://sky-proj-sky.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/getting-started/quickstart.html#hello-sky.  Get right to the action.
- (say manually copy paste this file, maybe) - Kevin is confused that examples/ doesn’t contain hello_sky.  Add hello_sky from quickstart to examples/ in sky repo (make life easier for user)
- We should mention how long it takes to provision in the docs (3-4 min)
- Specify cluster name (Kevin forgot about this) and/or make it much more obvious

title: Base conda environment causes dependency issues
body:
There was a lot of friction around installing Sky in the base conda environment due to package conflicts and creating a new conda environment without python=3.8 resulted in the env using system pip (not good!).

Actions (Zhanghao/Siyuan): 
- Version conflict issue: unclear whether pinning requests/urllib3 fixes it
  - Could it be a python2 issue?
- Suggest in docs that you can “conda create -n sky python=3.8”
- Why not provide our own image? This addresses a lot issues (slow start, incorrect configuration, incorrect python shell, conflict packages, missing dependencies)

title: Fix sky check showing AWS:enabled even when `aws configure` is not run
body: `sky check` incorrectly showed that AWS was available to use but an extra `aws configure` was required for Sky to actually view that AWS is available and include it in optimizer/provisioner.

title: Docs: Add instructions for finding subscription ID in Azure
body: It is not obvious how to do this for new users.

title: Fix ulimit for provision
body:
Closes #271. This PR fixes the permission denied for `ulimit -n 65535` to improve the performance according to ray docs ("Make sure ulimit -n is set to at least 65535. Ray opens many direct connections between worker processes to avoid bottlenecks, so it can quickly use a large number of file descriptors."). https://docs.ray.io/en/latest/cluster/guide.html?highlight=ulimit#system-configuration

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml`
- [x] `sky launch -c min --cloud azure ./examples/minimal.yaml`
- [x] `sky launch -c min --cloud gcp ./examples/minimal.yaml`

title: Added FileLock on cluster launch and teardown
body:
Solves #455 by adding a lock around cluster launch and teardown.

Test:

1. run `sky cpunode` from one terminal
2. while its running try `sky down sky-cpunode` from another: returns  `Cluster is locked. Check to see if it is still being launched.`
3. terminate `sky cpunode`
4. retry `sky down` and see it succeed

Possibly could hold the lock for less time but since down and crucial, I think it makes sense to hold throughout the entire process.

title: Timeout for multi-node launching
body:
This is to resolve #502. We will timeout the gang scheduling if we fail to launch at least 1 node in 30 seconds when there is any node that should be launched (launch means: provision without any setup). The fail case relates to quota limit or resources availability limit. We can further reduce the `timeout` to simulate the AWS UI behavior as mentioned in #502 (head node still needs to be provisioned first), but it will disable the retry for resources availability.

This also fixes a problem in #413, where `ray exec 'ray status'` fails, by caching the head_ip by ourselves.

PS: I changed the `upscaling_speed` to `num_nodes - 1`, so that ray will try to launch all the worker nodes when the heads are ready (increasing the parallelism), instead of `upscaling_speed * ready_nodes` each time. (Side effect: it will launch as many instances as possible and then teardown them, if the resources is not enough).

Tested (the following cluster `scale-n` indicates cluster with `num_nodes=n`:
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-3 examples/minimal.yaml` (it fails from the first region in 4 min (start from `sky launch`) due to the quota limit, and then successfully launched on the second region in min).
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-1000 examples/minimal.yaml` (it fails all the aws regions in 12 min)
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-18 examples/minimal.yaml` (Daniel's usecase, it takes 10 min (4min of it fails from the first region) to provision the instances)
  ```
  sky launch -c scale-18 --cloud aws examples/minimal.yaml  28.11s user 8.40s system 5% cpu 10:13.99 total
  ```
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-3 --cloud gcp examples/minimal.yaml` 
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-3 --cloud azure examples/minimal.yaml` 
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-1000 --cloud gcp examples/minimal.yaml` (timeout all the region/zones within 1:40:00)
- [x] `sky launch -c scale-1000 --cloud azure examples/minimal.yaml` (timeout all the region/zones within 4:15:00, the mainly reason is that launching and terminating on azure is very slow)
- [x] `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh` (Tested with azure_start_stop disabled)

Note: the time for scale-1000 is still not good especially for azure and gcp, but at least it is better than before, which will hang forever.

Future TODO: check the quota before we call the `ray up` so we can get rid of the long waiting time for the quota limit.

title: Fix Azure resource leak
body:
Unfortunately I cannot reproduce the bug with my laptop. But it looks like the valid fix. @infwinston Could you try this simple fix?

BTW, we are still leaking other resources for all clouds (because of design of Ray autoscaler), e.g., credentials and security configurations. Not sure if there are limits of these resources. Check https://portal.azure.com/#blade/HubsExtension/BrowseResourceGroups for details. title: [docker] Change remote working directory into `/sky_workdir`
body:
This PR fixes the name of the remote working directory when using the local docker backend: from `f"/{task.work_dir}"` to `/sky_workdir`.

This PR also fixes #303 , a failure from `--workdir .`. The source of the bug was `shutil.copytree(copy_path, dst=f'{tempdir}/{task.workdir}')`; because `shutil.copytree` requires `dst` not already exist, `dst` must not be `f'{tempdir}/.'`. Thus, this PR fixes `dst` to `f'{tempdir}/sky_workdir'`.

title: Fast one-to-all file_mounts
body:
The current parallel file_mounts implementation only takes advantage of the parallelism on the local laptop. The network bandwidth of the remote clusters is not fully utilized. I can imagine there will be many different algorithms (maybe become a research topic) we can think of to increase the utilization of the bandwidth during syncing files to multiple nodes. 

1. Local -> head; head to all the nodes (pipelining and utilizing the faster internal network)
2. Local -> head; head to all the nodes with tree-style (or other algorithms, like p2p?) syncing. (utilize more node-node connection)
3. Partition the file and pipeline the transfer. (proposed by @infwinston)
4. Some more heuristic algorithm that can adjust the strategy based on the real network bandwidth.

title: Enable the higher-level caller of cloud_vm_ray_backend to handle the failure
body:
Currently, we `sys.exit` in the `cloud_vm_ray_backend` to suppress the traceback and unnecessary output when an error occurs. This may be hard for the high-level caller to handle the failure.

Quoting from @romilbhardwaj in #458 
> Let's leave it be for now for the sake of consistency, but I think this is generally not a good pattern since it prohibits higher-level callers from handling failures. Ideally, we should raise an exception (and if we need to suppress traceback, do something like [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/27680034) or [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/27674608)).

title: We should not upload user credentials

title: Fix credential mounting
body:
Closes #480. This problem was introduced by #407, as we removed the file_mounts from the ray yaml and the credentials for the cloud storage are not uploaded to the server. The reason #480 only happens for multiple nodes is that ray will upload the aws credential to the head node when using aws ec2, but not the worker nodes.

Tested:
- [x] Mounting s3 bucket that requires credential on multiple nodes. `s3://fah-public-data-covid19-cryptic-pockets/human/il6/PROJ14534/RUN999/CLONE0/results0`
- [x] Mounting gcs bucket that requires credential on single node.
- [x] Mounting gcs bucket that requires credential on multiple nodes.

title: [Feature request] Priority-based partitions for job queue
body:
Users may have several kinds of jobs, some more important than others:
- `hi-pri`: Needs to be run as soon as possible -- not meant to be used in normal circumstances (e.g. emergency production job required for paper submission, data preprocessing job blocking other work from happening, etc.)
- `regular`: Normal job queue behavior (e.g. hyperparam sweep, experiments, etc.)
- `low-pri`: Maybe a random idea the user wants to try out or high-variance experiment which doesn't need to be run instantly but can run when cluster is idle (ok if it gets starved a bit)

Within each of these partitions FIFO behavior is ok. If the cluster is full, submission of a higher priority partition always causes jobs from a lower priority partition to freeze, starting from the lowest partition up.

We will need to assume the user has some sort of checkpointing mechanism implemented (which is also a requirement for spot instance fault-tolerance efforts as well). For machine learning workloads, assuming the user has checkpointing implemented in their application is reasonable.

Happy to discuss more!

title: Fix `sky logs` with interactive ssh causing job status wrongly set if ctrl-c'ed
body:
This PR fixes the following problem introduced by #454, due to the `-tt` option added to the `ssh` for `sky logs`

1. `sky logs min 1` and then Ctrl-C at the proper time (during the L295 in `job_lib.py` is updating the job status using `ray job status`)
2. The Ctrl-C will be received by the `ray job status`, since `ssh -tt` will pass Ctrl-C to the remote process and kill it.
3. As the `ray job status` is killed, the output does not have the required status of the job, and sky will set the job to `FAILED`, though it is still running.

To fix this problem this PR changes the `sky logs` read-only for the job table. 

A future note: we should make sure all the interactive mode ssh be read-only to the job table.

title: Simple SSH into Multi-node Workers from Local
body:
## PR Details
Resolves #457 and #252. This issue also affected our initial user and affected my debugging iteration speed when working with Multinode setups. Hence, here is a fix to make everyone's lives easier.

Now any user can easily ssh into worker nodes. Suppose there are `3` nodes in the cluster named `hello`.
```
# SSH into head node
ssh hello 
# SSH into Worker 1
ssh hello-worker1
# SSH into Worker 2 
ssh hello-worker2
```

## Tests

`sky launch -c examples/env_check.yaml` with 3 nodes
`~/.ssh/config:`
```
Include /Users/michaelluo/.sky/ssh/hello

# Added by sky (use `sky stop/down-c hello` to remove)
Host hello
  HostName 54.91.127.194
  User ubuntu
  IdentityFile /Users/michaelluo/.ssh/sky-key
  IdentitiesOnly yes
  ForwardAgent yes
  StrictHostKeyChecking no
  Port 22
```

`sky down hello`
`~/.ssh/config` is empty and `~/.sky/ssh/hello` is gone


*Note*: SSH to Worker from Head is not done. It is a lot more invovled.

title: Cluster (auto or manual) downsizing, when some nodes have been idle
body:
From Daniel:
> One thing I'd like to do now, which I think is pretty common, is to kill training jobs that are doing poorly. I can kill the jobs using wandb, but then I'm still going to be paying for the GPUs, and I don't have other stuff to sky exec on this cluster yet. (Given 18 hyperparameter configurations, I could've instead set up a cluster with 6 GPUs, queued up 18 jobs, and then killed jobs as I determined that they were doing poorly. But then I'd have to wait much longer for the final answer.) Is there some way/are you planning to implement some way to dynamically resize a cluster? Maybe a command to shut down any machines that don't currently have something sky exec ing on them? It seems like all the sky commands operate on clusters rather than individual machines.
[thread](https://learningsystems.slack.com/archives/C034B5MARD3/p1645933789034269)

> in the meantime, I do actually want to shut down most but not all of the machines in my cluster so that I can stop paying for instances I'm not using. I tried manually stopping the idle instances in the AWS console, but sky/ray keeps turning them back on. Is there any way around this? I could down the whole cluster and then restart the jobs that are still running from checkpoints, but that's a bit of a pain
[thread](https://learningsystems.slack.com/archives/C034B5MARD3/p1646013999772119)

See the above slack threads for some more discussion.

I believe the major  motivation behind this ask is to **save costs**.

Currently, he doesn't have a problem of saving artifacts ("At the moment I'm uploading model checkpoints to wandb"), so it should be ok to turn off the machines (if not for the autoscaler to immediately launch them back on).

title: [logging/ux] Finer-grained hints during provisioning

> I ran sky gpunode and it took just under 4 minutes until I was dropped into a shell on the remote machine. Is this expected? title: Make GPU/TPU names case-insensitive
body:
This PR closes #450 
For example, now `--gpus t4` is allowed in addition to `--gpus T4`.

I feel my code is a bit hacky, but couldn't find a better way of implementation. Please feel free to request any changes.

title: [Sky Launch] Replace `--gpus` arg with `--accelerators`?
body: Currently, `sky launch` only has `gpus` argument, so cannot launch TPU jobs without a yaml file. Why don't we extend `--gpus` to `--accelerators` (plus `--accelerator_args`) for completeness?

title: Using Ray for the local backend?
body: A quick question after meeting with Ion: what is the reason for not using Ray as our local backend? I'm just curious..

title: [Azure] Downgrade the image version for K80 instances
body:
Fixes #449 and probably closes #133 

I found that the MS-DSVM image v21.08.30 uses NVIDIA driver 470, which does not incur the GPU loading error on Ubuntu machines. Let's use this version of image until Azure releases a new fixed image for K80.

title: Suppress rsync output
body:
Closes #438 

~~Waiting for #458~~

title: Parallel Setup + Filemounting
body:
This PR address #453. This speeds up setup and filemounting via parallel threads.

## Tests
```
resources:
  cloud: aws

num_nodes: 2  

workdir: .

setup: |
  echo "here"
  echo "export TEST_VAR=test" >> ~/.bashrc

file_mounts:
  /sky: ~/Downloads/temp
  ~/tmpfile: ~/tmpfile


run: |
  if [[ -z "${TEST_VAR}" ]]; then
    echo "TEST_VAR is not set"
    exit 1
  else
    echo "TEST_VAR is set to ${TEST_VAR}"
  fi

  if [[ -d ~/sky_workdir/sky ]]; then
    echo "~/sky_workdir/sky exists"
  else
    echo "~/sky_workdir/sky does not exist"
    exit 1
  fi

  echo NODE ID: $SKY_NODE_RANK
  echo NODE IPS: "$SKY_NODE_IPS"
  worker_addr=`echo "$SKY_NODE_IPS" | sed -n 2p`
  echo Worker IP: $worker_addr

```

title: [Feature Request] `ssh [clustername]-w1` Easy way to SSH into Worker Nodes

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
Is there an easy way to ssh into work nodes (other than `ssh [ip of workder node]`)? @gmittal If so, close this issue. Ideally, I want something like `ssh [clustername]-w[worker_node_idx]` to check if setup and filemounting is working on the workernode.

Otherwise, when I run `sky status` on multinode setup, there is no way to tell if there are additional names associated with the worker nodes.

title: Multinode `SKY_NODE_RANK` not available during Setup
body:
It is possible that setup may differ between nodes. In that case, having access `SKY_NODE_RANK` is important during setup.
## Reproduction
```
resources:
  cloud: aws

num_nodes: 2  

workdir: .

setup: |
  echo "here"
  echo "export TEST_VAR=test" >> ~/.bashrc
  echo NODE ID: $SKY_NODE_RANK
```
Outputs:
```
here
NODE ID:
```

title: Fix delayed logs of `sky logs` locally vs `tail -f` remotely
body:
Closes #451 

The previous delay can be as large as 5 minutes. I did the following changes to optimize the situation.
1. ~~Using the `ray job logs` instead of our self-implemented busy for loop for tailing the log file. (`ray job` API has a shorter calling path)~~ I have to bring back our own log tailing function, since the `ray job logs` does not handle progress bar correctly.
2. Change the SshMode for log tailing to `Interactive`, so that the `ssh` buffer is disabled.
3. Remove the log redirecting and parsing for the `subprocess` for the log tailing.

The first two modifications reduce the logging delay from 5 min to around 6 seconds. The last modification reduces the logging delay to within 1 second by eyes. After changing back the log tailing function to our own, the time delay is still within 1 second.

Tested:
`sky launch -c test-log examples/resnet_app.yaml` (changed the `train_steps` to 25000)
- [x]  Compare `sky logs test-log 1` vs `ssh test-log; tail -f ./sky_logs/.../run.log`
- [x]  Compare `sky exec test-log "tail -f ./sky_logs/.../run.log"` vs `ssh test-log; tail -f ./sky_logs/.../run.log`

body: Multinode setup and filemounting too slow! Must be done in Parallel

title: `sky logs` has large delay compares to the real logs
body: This is an observation from @dhroth where the `sky logs` has a large delay of the actual log written in the `sky_logs/` folder. By experiments with the `resnet_app.yaml` with the `train_steps=25000`. It has up to 5-minute delay of the logs between `sky logs ` and the real logs. It seems like the problem is caused by the buffering or other text holding reason caused by `ssh`.

title: GPU name in lower case
body: Currently, sky only accepts the GPU name in upper case (whereas TPU types must be written in lower case). It would be convenient for users to write the GPU/TPU names in either uppercase or lowercase.

title: [Azure] Cuda driver fails on Azure's K80 gpunode
body:
Looks like the image `microsoft-dsvm` we're based on doesn't work on Azure's K80 instance. Thanks @WoosukKwon for reporting this.
```
azureuser@ray-sky-gpunode-weichiang-head-9ecb80c80:~$ nvidia-smi
NVIDIA-SMI has failed because it couldn't communicate with the NVIDIA driver. Make sure that the latest NVIDIA driver is installed and running.
```

title: Fix gitignore for rsync
body: Closes #445, and also removes some unuseful `rsync_filter` fields mentioned in #438.

title: [Feature request] How to check the GPU quota with Sky?
body:
Question from Daniel: is there any way to check the EC2 quota with Sky?
Also, should we direct users how to bump quota or even support ways to do it on behalf of users?

title: File mounting a `.gitignore`-ed subdir of workdir
body:
Daniel told us he'd like to upload some git repo under his workdir but Sky won't upload it as it's listed in `.gitignore`. Seems to me we wrongly assumed that those not be version controlled and those not required during runtime to be the same.
Do we need a `.skyignore` file instead of just using `.gitignore`?
